title: Will Anyone Watch a TV Show About Streetwear? Amazon’s ‘Fairfax’ Is Betting Yes.
sub_head: Amazon Prime’s new adult animated series takes aim at sneaker obsessing and hoodie hoarding. But the show may be too niche for its own good.
body:
In the premiere episode of Amazon Prime’s new animated show “Fairfax,” a group of clout-hungry teenagers attempts to track down a limited-edition T-shirt from Latrine, a fictional streetwear brand that is a thinly veiled sendup of Supreme. The show is overstuffed with knowing references to hype-happy streetwear in the real world: The animated quartet name-drops Grailed, a resale site; the characters lust after decade-plus-old Nike Dunks; and the shirt they’re after carries Dr. Phil’s face, a nod to head-scratcher Supreme collaborations which featured images of Kermit the Frog or Shrek.
In the mold of long-running cartoons like “The Simpsons,” “South Park” and Netflix ’s recently finished “BoJack Horseman,” “Fairfax” is an animated show for adults that lampoons American culture. (Peppered with f-bombs, this is not a show to watch with your tween.) Whereas “BoJack Horseman” sunk its teeth into Hollywood, “Fairfax” takes aim at social-media addiction and the rabid fashion consumerism. (One of the executive producers of “Fairfax” worked on “BoJack.”)
